lead: Port Angeles Fire Department (PAFD) and Local 656 establish the framework for a Community Paramedic Program.
bullets: Conducted community needs assessment identifying high system utilizers
Signed MOU with Local 656 to support pilot program
Developed protocols with Clallam County Medical Program Director
Secured initial partnerships with OMC, PBH, and NOHN

lead: Implemented the Community Paramedic program by reallocating a Firefighter/Paramedic from line staff as a one-year pilot.
need: High system utilizers were overusing 9-1-1 and the Emergency Department for non-emergent medical needs, creating strain on emergency resources.
response: Launched a one-year pilot program reallocating a Firefighter/Paramedic to focus on bridging healthcare gaps. Established partnerships with OMC, PBH, and NOHN.
impact: Successfully established a new care pathway for chronic conditions, reducing immediate pressure on emergency services and proving the viability of the Community Paramedic model.

lead: North Olympic Healthcare Network and PAFD collaborated through United Healthcare Fund grant dollars to augment and sustain the program.
need: The pilot program demonstrated value but required sustainable funding and staffing to meet growing community demand, especially with the onset of the pandemic.
response: Secured United Healthcare Fund grant dollars through NOHN collaboration. Hired three community paramedics and expanded scope to include in-home assessments.
impact: Secured program continuity and expanded care coordination capabilities, allowing for robust response during the public health emergency.

lead: Rapidly adapted scope of practice to support the community during the COVID-19 public health emergency.
bullets: Conducted home visits for vulnerable populations
Facilitated vaccinations for home-bound individuals
Provided bridge care to reduce hospital exposure risks
Implemented harm reduction initiatives including 'Sharps' containers

lead: A pivotal year of growth: hiring full-time staff, launching 'Treat & Release' protocols, and leading regional vaccination efforts.
need: The pandemic created urgent gaps in care (vaccinations, home-bound patients) while the program needed to formalize its clinical role to handle higher acuity cases in the field.
response: Hired Community Paramedic Brian Gerdes (Jan) and Community Paramedic Kristin Fox (July). Launched 'Treat & Release' protocols for point-of-care labs and IV therapy.
impact: Delivered ~600 COVID-19 vaccine doses to home-bound residents, established point-of-care lab testing, and integrated with EPIC EHR for seamless care continuity.
bullets: Hired Community Paramedic Brian Gerdes (Jan) and Community Paramedic Kristin Fox (July)
Launched 'Treat & Release' protocols for point-of-care labs and IV therapy
Delivered ~600 COVID-19 vaccine doses to home-bound residents
Integrated with EPIC EHR for seamless care continuity
Partnered with OPCC and Rediscovery for street outreach

lead: Scaled operations to address the rising tide of behavioral health crises and overdose fatalities.
need: Identified a sharp increase in overdose fatalities and behavioral health crises in the community, necessitating a more specialized response.
response: Secured Clallam County Behavioral Health Advisory Board (BHAB) grant funding. Launched LEAD Fire alternative response program.
impact: Expanded service delivery to include long-acting injectables and alternative response pathways, directly targeting the most vulnerable populations.

lead: Strategic shift to address the escalating opioid epidemic and high overdose fatality rates.
need: Clallam County ranked 4th highest in the state for overdose fatalities. 60% of survivors refused treatment, and there were 0% MOUD referrals.
response: Initiated 'Operation Shielding Hope' and secured Opioid Settlement Funds. Began investigating barriers to care and refusal rates.
impact: Laid the groundwork for the Post Overdose Response Team (PORT) and secured funding for dedicated emergency response units.

lead: Secured historic approval from WA Department of Health to launch the Post Overdose Response Team (PORT) pilot, expanding scope to include field-based Buprenorphine.
need: Overdose survivors were refusing transport (60% refusal rate) and getting stuck in a cycle of repeat overdoses due to precipitated withdrawal.
response: Obtained DOH approval to expand scope of practice, allowing field administration of Buprenorphine (MOUD) and 24/7 response capability.
impact: Enabled 'warm handoffs' to treatment. Achieved 78% linkage to SUD services when CPMs respond, compared to only 3% without them.
bullets: Authorized to administer Buprenorphine (MOUD) in the field to treat precipitated withdrawal
Established 24/7 response capability for overdose incidents
Implemented 'warm handoff' protocols with 78% linkage success rate
Partnered with PAPD Community Resource Officer for co-response

lead: Systematized the referral process for off-hour overdoses.
bullets: Implemented protocol for on-duty shift personnel to refer survivors
Ensured 100% of off-hour overdoses are referred to CPM office
Closed the gap on missed opportunities during nights and weekends

lead: Awarded a $350,000 innovation grant from the University of Washington and Co-responder Outreach Alliance to deploy autonomous response units.
need: The demand for overdose response required dedicated resources that wouldn't deplete standard 9-1-1 emergency units.
response: Utilized $350,000 grant to hire two Community EMTs and deploy two autonomous Post Overdose Response Units.
impact: Broadened 9-1-1 response capability, allowing CPMs to operate independently and relieve pressure on fire engines and ambulances.
bullets: Hired two Community EMTs to staff dedicated response vehicles
Deployed two autonomous Post Overdose Response Units (non-transport)
Relieved pressure on 9-1-1 system by handling low-acuity calls independently
Broadened emergency services response capability for the entire city

lead: Presented progress update and SUD program outcomes to the Behavioral Health Advisory Board.
bullets: Highlighted 70% success rate for PORT arrivals
Reported decreased first responder compassion fatigue
Outlined future goals for field clearance and MOUD upon discharge

lead: Significant reduction in overdose fatalities and improved community health outcomes.
need: In early 2024, Clallam County had the 2nd highest overdose death rate in WA (73.3 per 100k). Compassion fatigue was high among first responders.
response: Full implementation of PORT with warm handoffs. 100% of off-hour overdoses referred to CPM. 70%+ acceptance into MOUD/MAT services.
impact: By Jan 2025, county ranking dropped to 10th (41.2 per 100k). Achieved $524,124 in cost savings and prevented 118 9-1-1 calls.

lead: Presented 'Operation Shielding Hope' outcomes to the Port Angeles City Council.
bullets: Reported 63% decrease in fatal overdoses over 12 months
Highlighted $1.89M in total estimated cost savings since program inception
Confirmed 100% referral rate for off-hour overdoses

lead: Continued decline in overdose rates and sustained program success.
need: The need to maintain momentum in overdose prevention and ensure long-term recovery support for survivors.
response: Continued PORT operations and expansion of MOUD services. Strengthened partnerships with jail and hospital systems.
impact: County ranking dropped further to 11th (34.8 per 100k). Recorded a 63% decrease in fatal overdoses over a 12-month period.
